pr_title: [TA] Changes based on V3.0 swagger, etc

timeline.message: regenerated code using swagger
only detected language is not working
everything works beside exception thrown has not been take care
throw HttpResponseException and added tests corresponding to it
update readme with embededme
subCategory, sub-category to subcategory

timeline.bodyText: Not so sure, but I see that AnalyzeSentimentResultImpl isn't a generated class but we still have it under implementation.models package?
timeline.author: samvaity

replies.bodyText: Is that the new design change so that we avoid having public constructors in our model?
replies.author: samvaity

replies.bodyText: Yes. It is. We explore AnalyzeSentimentResult interface to user but hide the implementation of it in implementation folder.
replies.author: mssfang

replies.bodyText: interface approach is no longer a option. keep as original design, adding overload constructor and deprecate constructor as needed.
replies.author: mssfang

timeline.message: not throw exception but return it for async apis and added tests
add text to sentenceSentiment and add warning support
checkstyle

replies.bodyText:
Currently, with new swagger changes, the service returns TextAnalyticsErrrorException, Which will not explore to user. We want to explore HttpResponseException to user for the exception return from service side. In async APIs, we never throw exception but return Mono/Flux errors.
For your question: " For single document calls, you're now throwing on errors?"
If you are talking about, "if there is partial success in a batch operation, throwing an error", the answer is noop.
.onErrorMap() will only be triggeed when the service restful call entitiesLinkingWithResponseAsync has failed, which is the request call failure.
replies.author: mssfang

replies.bodyText: If the error happen that early, can you map the error in early phase before mapping page result?
replies.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: this is the earliest stage. service.entitiesLinkingWithResponseAsync() is the restful API, when it throws exceptions. we map the exception directily.
replies.author: mssfang

timeline.bodyText: Are you trying to fit this todo in your pr?
timeline.author: iscai-msft

replies.bodyText: I think it is doable. #10664
replies.author: mssfang

replies.bodyText: It will no longer an issue now. It will throw TextAnalyticsException but not HttpResponseException. Because HttpResponseException can only be raised when network call failed. In this case,  it is not.
replies.author: mssfang

replies.bodyText: @iscai-msft Wouldn't that apply to Python as well? It not being a service failure i.e not an HttpResponseException?
replies.author: samvaity

timeline.bodyText: It appears you've removed the check for null documents and haven't added in a call to your inputDocumentsValidation utility function (also seeing other instances of this)
timeline.author: iscai-msft

replies.bodyText: Async API will never throw an exception but return the error. It is handled in https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/pull/10593/files/35656e916f51de922508097123cab21513543620#diff-b7e39c6a437cc9256cc5cf809bf8531dR855
replies.author: mssfang

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't it be better to make a call to inputDocumentsValidation here instead of calling Objects.requireNonNull? You can either make your inputDpcumentsValidation function take in strings as well as iterable of strings with an overload, or pass in the document in an array of 1
timeline.author: iscai-msft

replies.bodyText: 'InputDocumentValidation' is a helper method for a list of documents, documents. It checks 'documents' is not null and not empty. But here, the input is a single document, 'document', so it won't apply here.
replies.author: mssfang

replies.bodyText:
Python isn't returning a CategorizedEntityCollection, only Java and .Net are, so @maririos
knows better here. We just have the categorized entities on RecognizeEntitiesResult
replies.author: iscai-msft

replies.bodyText:
we follow this patter in .NET.
In .NET, when a property ends with Collection it means it extends from Collection, which in our case is true.
Not sure if Java has something similar where with the name, the user will now that it inherits from IterableStream
replies.author: maririos

replies.bodyText:
It is a single-input API. Only .NET and Java has it.
FYI: https://gist.github.com/mssfang/5d7097c3d859c2087b34e544c4f7ee3f#proporsal-1-which-aligned-with-net-design

replies.bodyText: in this case, since it is single-input API, which take one input document. But internally, we call the batch API. Which could have the result is error document. If the result is error, for single-input API, we throw the TextAnalyticsException but not return error.

It will be more obvious if we have text in different languages.

timeline.bodyText:
Sorry I was wrong when I suggested this, I didn't realize that this TextDocumentInput constructor didn't take language. I'm confused though: it looks like in master you had two constructors: one that took language, one that did not.
I think you should still have two constructors here like in master. For the one that doesn't take language as a parameter, it should set this.language = "en", since that is the default. Otherwise, this.language = language
timeline.author: iscai-msft

replies.bodyText: if in the future, the default lanauge is change to 'es. we need to update it to es`. Since service team take default value in service side, we should not add what they are maintaining here. So keep no-assigned in SDK should be an better idea.
replies.author: mssfang

timeline.message: wording and setter

timeline.bodyText:
i'm not sure i understand the context on just making setLanguage a setter and not adding it to a separate constructor like you used to have it. Is there a reason why you can't add this constructor back like it is in master: 
  
    
      azure-sdk-for-java/sdk/textanalytics/azure-ai-textanalytics/src/main/java/com/azure/ai/textanalytics/models/TextDocumentInput.java
    
    
         Line 50
      in
      fcdaff1
    
    
    
    

        
          
           public TextDocumentInput(String id, String text, String language) { 
        
    
  


I really don't think it's a good idea to force users to call TextDocumentInput.setLanguage("en") for the most basic version of TextDocumentInput (you're doing this in your tests). What I think you should do is have two constructors exactly how it is in master. Is there a reason why you're changing this code?
timeline.author: iscai-msft

replies.bodyText: the only time constructor needed is when the parameter is required. But since language is optional. it should not go to constructor. Let's say maybe in the future, more parameter will be added to this class, we will not add another constructor if the value is not required.
replies.author: mssfang
